newsitem.title: UK: SOCCER-UNITED RUN RIOT AS JUVE AND AJAX FALTER.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-UNITED RUN RIOT AS JUVE AND AJAX FALTER.

text.p: Manchester United all but booked a place in their first European Cup semifinal for 28 years when they swept aside Porto 4-0 on Wednesday night in the first leg of their quarter-final tie.

But while United were thriving, holders Juventus, who beat the English champions twice in the Champions' League phase of the competition, were held 1-1 in Norway by Rosenborg Trondheim, conquerors of AC Milan in December.
Borussia Dortmund took a decisive step towards the last four by beating Auxerre 3-1 while Ajax, champions in 1995 and beaten finalists last year, were held 1-1 in Amsterdam by Atletico Madrid.
Porto's 4-0 drubbing at Old Trafford was their first defeat of the current European campaign and only their second of the season in all competitions.
It was their first defeat away from home since March 23, 1996, when the lost 2-1 at Benfica in the Portuguese league.
United played with a confidence they lacked in the group phase late last year.

The first goal came when David Beckham's looping cross from the left flank was headed goalwards by Gary Pallister. Goalkeeper Hilario could only parry and Pallister's fellow centre-back David May bundled the ball over the line.

Eric Cantona made the score 2-0 when he took advantage of a mistake by Paulinho Santos to lash the ball under Hilario's body from 12 metres and Ryan Giggs added to the 21-year-old goalkeeper's nightmare when he squeezed a shot inside the near post to round off a superb move started by Cantona deep in United territory.
The Frenchman was again the provider for Cole to claim a coolly-taken United fourth.
Alex Ferguson's side will travel to Portugal in confident mood but nevertheless wary of historical precedents.

The last time these two sides met, in the Cup Winners' Cup quarter-finals 19 years ago, Porto won the first leg 4-0. They then almost threw the tie away at Old Trafford in the second leg, losing 5-2 to edge through 6-5 on aggregate.
Juventus, who -- like Porto -- came through the Champions' League phase undefeated, were badly hit by injuries and looking sluggish on a freezing night in Trondheim.
Rosenborg took a deserved lead six minutes into the second half when striker Trond Egil Soltvedt hooked the ball home after a goalmouth melee.

But as the capacity Norwegian crowd celebrated, Juve's makeshift attacking pairing of Michele Padovano and Christian Vieri combined and Vieri nodded home a simple header to give the Italians an invaluable away goal for the second leg in two weeks' time.
Juve will be keen to welcome back Alessandro Del Piero and Croat Alan Boksic for the return match in Turin.
Ajax, Juve's victims in last year's European Cup final, face the threat of elimination and the end of their disappointing season after their 1-1 home draw against the champions of Spain.
Argentine international Juan Esnaider put Atletico ahead with a header in the eighth minute before Patrick Kluivert equalised for the Dutch side early in the second half.
Kluivert received his second booking of the competition and will miss the second leg in Madrid.
Goals by Karlheinz Riedle, Rene Schneider and Andy Moeller gave Dortmund a valuable victory against Auxerre.

Riedle headed Dortmund's first from close range after a fine build-up from Joerg Heinrich and Swiss international striker Stephane Chapuisat, and Schneider, a first-half substitute for injured Wolfgang Feiersinger, scored a second header early in the second half.
Sabri Lamouchi reduced the deficit before Moeller gave the German champions a comfortable cushion for the away leg with a lethal finish eight minutes from time.
Dortmund's night was soured slightly by the dismissal of Stefan Reuter three minutes from time for a second bookable offence. The German international will miss the return match in France.
